Parsing [sent. 3 len. 57]: Yet notwithstanding it is only a record of a pic-nic , it has a purpose , which is to suggest to the reader how he would be likely to see Europe and the East if he looked at them with his own eyes instead of the eyes of those who traveled in those countries before him .
Parsing [sent. 4 len. 42]: I make small pretense of showing anyone how he ought to look at objects of interest beyond the sea -- other books do that , and therefore , even if I were competent to do it , there is no need .

Parsing [sent. 10 len. 29]: CHAPTER I. For months the great pleasure excursion to Europe and the Holy Land was chatted about in the newspapers everywhere in America and discussed at countless firesides .
Parsing [sent. 11 len. 30]: It was a novelty in the way of excursions -- its like had not been thought of before , and it compelled that interest which attractive novelties always command .
Parsing [sent. 12 len. 11]: It was to be a picnic on a gigantic scale .
Parsing [sent. 13 len. 93]: The participants in it , instead of freighting an ungainly steam ferry -- boat with youth and beauty and pies and doughnuts , and paddling up some obscure creek to disembark upon a grassy lawn and wear themselves out with a long summer day 's laborious frolicking under the impression that it was fun , were to sail away in a great steamship with flags flying and cannon pealing , and take a royal holiday beyond the broad ocean in many a strange clime and in many a land renowned in history !
Parsing [sent. 14 len. 213]: They were to sail for months over the breezy Atlantic and the sunny Mediterranean ; they were to scamper about the decks by day , filling the ship with shouts and laughter -- or read novels and poetry in the shade of the smokestacks , or watch for the jelly-fish and the nautilus over the side , and the shark , the whale , and other strange monsters of the deep ; and at night they were to dance in the open air , on the upper deck , in the midst of a ballroom that stretched from horizon to horizon , and was domed by the bending heavens and lighted by no meaner lamps than the stars and the magnificent moon -- dance , and promenade , and smoke , and sing , and make love , and search the skies for constellations that never associate with the `` Big Dipper '' they were so tired of ; and they were to see the ships of twenty navies -- the customs and costumes of twenty curious peoples -- the great cities of half a world -- they were to hob-nob with nobility and hold friendly converse with kings and princes , grand moguls , and the anointed lords of mighty empires !
Parsing [sent. 15 len. 16]: It was a brave conception ; it was the offspring of a most ingenious brain .
Parsing [sent. 16 len. 42]: It was well advertised , but it hardly needed it : the bold originality , the extraordinary character , the seductive nature , and the vastness of the enterprise provoked comment everywhere and advertised it in every household in the land .

Parsing [sent. 401 len. 11]: It is an accomplished sailor and has good sailor judgment .

Parsing [sent. 405 len. 25]: At three o'clock on the morning of the twenty-first of June , we were awakened and notified that the Azores islands were in sight .

Parsing [sent. 473 len. 3]: CHAPTER VI .
Parsing [sent. 474 len. 12]: I think the Azores must be very little known in America .
Parsing [sent. 475 len. 20]: Out of our whole ship 's company there was not a solitary individual who knew anything whatever about them .
Parsing [sent. 476 len. 47]: Some of the party , well read concerning most other lands , had no other information about the Azores than that they were a group of nine or ten small islands far out in the Atlantic , something more than halfway between New York and Gibraltar .
Parsing [sent. 477 len. 4]: That was all .
Parsing [sent. 478 len. 15]: These considerations move me to put in a paragraph of dry facts just here .
Parsing [sent. 479 len. 24]: The community is eminently Portuguese -- that is to say , it is slow , poor , shiftless , sleepy , and lazy .
Parsing [sent. 480 len. 33]: There is a civil governor , appointed by the King of Portugal , and also a military governor , who can assume supreme control and suspend the civil government at his pleasure .
Parsing [sent. 481 len. 13]: The islands contain a population of about 200,000 , almost entirely Portuguese .
Parsing [sent. 482 len. 19]: Everything is staid and settled , for the country was one hundred years old when Columbus discovered America .
Parsing [sent. 483 len. 19]: The principal crop is corn , and they raise it and grind it just as their great-great-great-grandfathers did .
Parsing [sent. 484 len. 57]: They plow with a board slightly shod with iron ; their trifling little harrows are drawn by men and women ; small windmills grind the corn , ten bushels a day , and there is one assistant superintendent to feed the mill and a general superintendent to stand by and keep him from going to sleep .
Parsing [sent. 485 len. 45]: When the wind changes they hitch on some donkeys and actually turn the whole upper half of the mill around until the sails are in proper position , instead of fixing the concern so that the sails could be moved instead of the mill .
Parsing [sent. 486 len. 18]: Oxen tread the wheat from the ear , after the fashion prevalent in the time of Methuselah .
Parsing [sent. 487 len. 41]: There is not a wheelbarrow in the land -- they carry everything on their heads , or on donkeys , or in a wicker-bodied cart , whose wheels are solid blocks of wood and whose axles turn with the wheel .
Parsing [sent. 488 len. 14]: There is not a modern plow in the islands or a threshing machine .
Parsing [sent. 489 len. 8]: All attempts to introduce them have failed .
Parsing [sent. 490 len. 26]: The good Catholic Portuguese crossed himself and prayed God to shield him from all blasphemous desire to know more than his father did before him .
Parsing [sent. 491 len. 21]: The climate is mild ; they never have snow or ice , and I saw no chimneys in the town .
Parsing [sent. 492 len. 36]: The donkeys and the men , women , and children of a family all eat and sleep in the same room , and are unclean , are ravaged by vermin , and are truly happy .
Parsing [sent. 493 len. 23]: The people lie , and cheat the stranger , and are desperately ignorant , and have hardly any reverence for their dead .
Parsing [sent. 494 len. 18]: The latter trait shows how little better they are than the donkeys they eat and sleep with .
Parsing [sent. 495 len. 27]: The only well-dressed Portuguese in the camp are the half a dozen well-to-do families , the Jesuit priests , and the soldiers of the little garrison .
Parsing [sent. 496 len. 24]: The wages of a laborer are twenty to twenty-four cents a day , and those of a good mechanic about twice as much .
Parsing [sent. 497 len. 20]: They count it in reis at a thousand to the dollar , and this makes them rich and contented .
Parsing [sent. 498 len. 18]: Fine grapes used to grow in the islands , and an excellent wine was made and exported .
Parsing [sent. 499 len. 21]: But a disease killed all the vines fifteen years ago , and since that time no wine has been made .
Parsing [sent. 500 len. 15]: The islands being wholly of volcanic origin , the soil is necessarily very rich .
Parsing [sent. 501 len. 35]: Nearly every foot of ground is under cultivation , and two or three crops a year of each article are produced , but nothing is exported save a few oranges -- chiefly to England .
Parsing [sent. 502 len. 9]: Nobody comes here , and nobody goes away .
Parsing [sent. 503 len. 8]: News is a thing unknown in Fayal .
Parsing [sent. 504 len. 10]: A thirst for it is a passion equally unknown .
Parsing [sent. 505 len. 13]: A Portuguese of average intelligence inquired if our civil war was over .
Parsing [sent. 506 len. 29]: Because , he said , somebody had told him it was -- or at least it ran in his mind that somebody had told him something like that !
Parsing [sent. 507 len. 43]: And when a passenger gave an officer of the garrison copies of the Tribune , the Herald , and Times , he was surprised to find later news in them from Lisbon than he had just received by the little monthly steamer .
Parsing [sent. 508 len. 9]: He was told that it came by cable .
Parsing [sent. 509 len. 29]: He said he knew they had tried to lay a cable ten years ago , but it had been in his mind somehow that they had n't succeeded !
Parsing [sent. 510 len. 11]: It is in communities like this that Jesuit humbuggery flourishes .
Parsing [sent. 511 len. 27]: We visited a Jesuit cathedral nearly two hundred years old and found in it a piece of the veritable cross upon which our Saviour was crucified .
Parsing [sent. 512 len. 30]: It was polished and hard , and in as excellent a state of preservation as if the dread tragedy on Calvary had occurred yesterday instead of eighteen centuries ago .
Parsing [sent. 513 len. 12]: But these confiding people believe in that piece of wood unhesitatingly .
Parsing [sent. 514 len. 59]: In a chapel of the cathedral is an altar with facings of solid silver -- at least they call it so , and I think myself it would go a couple of hundred to the ton -LRB- to speak after the fashion of the silver miners -RRB- -- and before it is kept forever burning a small lamp .
Parsing [sent. 515 len. 36]: A devout lady who died , left money and contracted for unlimited masses for the repose of her soul , and also stipulated that this lamp should be kept lighted always , day and night .
Parsing [sent. 516 len. 11]: She did all this before she died , you understand .
Parsing [sent. 517 len. 30]: It is a very small lamp and a very dim one , and it could not work her much damage , I think , if it went out altogether .
Parsing [sent. 518 len. 23]: The great altar of the cathedral and also three or four minor ones are a perfect mass of gilt gimcracks and gingerbread .
Parsing [sent. 519 len. 72]: And they have a swarm of rusty , dusty , battered apostles standing around the filagree work , some on one leg and some with one eye out but a gamey look in the other , and some with two or three fingers gone , and some with not enough nose left to blow -- all of them crippled and discouraged , and fitter subjects for the hospital than the cathedral .
Parsing [sent. 520 len. 33]: The walls of the chancel are of porcelain , all pictured over with figures of almost life size , very elegantly wrought and dressed in the fanciful costumes of two centuries ago .
Parsing [sent. 521 len. 22]: The design was a history of something or somebody , but none of us were learned enough to read the story .
Parsing [sent. 522 len. 24]: The old father , reposing under a stone close by , dated 1686 , might have told us if he could have risen .
Parsing [sent. 523 len. 5]: But he did n't .
Parsing [sent. 524 len. 19]: As we came down through the town we encountered a squad of little donkeys ready saddled for use .
Parsing [sent. 525 len. 10]: The saddles were peculiar , to say the least .
Parsing [sent. 526 len. 23]: They consisted of a sort of saw-buck with a small mattress on it , and this furniture covered about half the donkey .
Parsing [sent. 527 len. 40]: There were no stirrups , but really such supports were not needed -- to use such a saddle was the next thing to riding a dinner table -- there was ample support clear out to one 's knee joints .
Parsing [sent. 528 len. 34]: A pack of ragged Portuguese muleteers crowded around us , offering their beasts at half a dollar an hour -- more rascality to the stranger , for the market price is sixteen cents .
Parsing [sent. 529 len. 32]: Half a dozen of us mounted the ungainly affairs and submitted to the indignity of making a ridiculous spectacle of ourselves through the principal streets of a town of 10,000 inhabitants .
Parsing [sent. 530 len. 3]: We started .
Parsing [sent. 531 len. 27]: It was not a trot , a gallop , or a canter , but a stampede , and made up of all possible or conceivable gaits .
Parsing [sent. 532 len. 5]: No spurs were necessary .
Parsing [sent. 533 len. 40]: There was a muleteer to every donkey and a dozen volunteers beside , and they banged the donkeys with their goad sticks , and pricked them with their spikes , and shouted something that sounded like `` Sekki-yah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 534 len. 15]: and kept up a din and a racket that was worse than Bedlam itself .
Parsing [sent. 535 len. 26]: These rascals were all on foot , but no matter , they were always up to time -- they can outrun and outlast a donkey .
Parsing [sent. 536 len. 22]: Altogether , ours was a lively and a picturesque procession , and drew crowded audiences to the balconies wherever we went .
Parsing [sent. 537 len. 10]: Blucher could do nothing at all with his donkey .
Parsing [sent. 538 len. 82]: The beast scampered zigzag across the road and the others ran into him ; he scraped Blucher against carts and the corners of houses ; the road was fenced in with high stone walls , and the donkey gave him a polishing first on one side and then on the other , but never once took the middle ; he finally came to the house he was born in and darted into the parlor , scraping Blucher off at the doorway .
Parsing [sent. 539 len. 25]: After remounting , Blucher said to the muleteer , `` Now , that 's enough , you know ; you go slow hereafter . ''
Parsing [sent. 540 len. 20]: But the fellow knew no English and did not understand , so he simply said , `` Sekki-yah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 541 len. 10]: and the donkey was off again like a shot .
Parsing [sent. 542 len. 13]: He turned a corner suddenly , and Blucher went over his head .
Parsing [sent. 543 len. 24]: And , to speak truly , every mule stumbled over the two , and the whole cavalcade was piled up in a heap .
Parsing [sent. 544 len. 4]: No harm done .
Parsing [sent. 545 len. 18]: A fall from one of those donkeys is of little more consequence than rolling off a sofa .
Parsing [sent. 546 len. 26]: The donkeys all stood still after the catastrophe and waited for their dismembered saddles to be patched up and put on by the noisy muleteers .
Parsing [sent. 547 len. 34]: Blucher was pretty angry and wanted to swear , but every time he opened his mouth his animal did so also and let off a series of brays that drowned all other sounds .
Parsing [sent. 548 len. 15]: It was fun , scurrying around the breezy hills and through the beautiful canyons .
Parsing [sent. 549 len. 35]: There was that rare thing , novelty , about it ; it was a fresh , new , exhilarating sensation , this donkey riding , and worth a hundred worn and threadbare home pleasures .
Parsing [sent. 550 len. 12]: The roads were a wonder , and well they might be .
Parsing [sent. 551 len. 32]: Here was an island with only a handful of people in it -- 25,000 -- and yet such fine roads do not exist in the United States outside of Central Park .
Parsing [sent. 552 len. 45]: Everywhere you go , in any direction , you find either a hard , smooth , level thoroughfare , just sprinkled with black lava sand , and bordered with little gutters neatly paved with small smooth pebbles , or compactly paved ones like Broadway .
Parsing [sent. 553 len. 38]: They talk much of the Russ pavement in New York , and call it a new invention -- yet here they have been using it in this remote little isle of the sea for two hundred years !
Parsing [sent. 554 len. 31]: Every street in Horta is handsomely paved with the heavy Russ blocks , and the surface is neat and true as a floor -- not marred by holes like Broadway .
Parsing [sent. 555 len. 27]: And every road is fenced in by tall , solid lava walls , which will last a thousand years in this land where frost is unknown .
Parsing [sent. 556 len. 20]: They are very thick , and are often plastered and whitewashed and capped with projecting slabs of cut stone .
Parsing [sent. 557 len. 30]: Trees from gardens above hang their swaying tendrils down , and contrast their bright green with the whitewash or the black lava of the walls and make them beautiful .
Parsing [sent. 558 len. 26]: The trees and vines stretch across these narrow roadways sometimes and so shut out the sun that you seem to be riding through a tunnel .
Parsing [sent. 559 len. 14]: The pavements , the roads , and the bridges are all government work .
Parsing [sent. 560 len. 32]: The bridges are of a single span -- a single arch -- of cut stone , without a support , and paved on top with flags of lava and ornamental pebblework .
Parsing [sent. 561 len. 37]: Everywhere are walls , walls , walls , and all of them tasteful and handsome -- and eternally substantial ; and everywhere are those marvelous pavements , so neat , so smooth , and so indestructible .
Parsing [sent. 562 len. 42]: And if ever roads and streets and the outsides of houses were perfectly free from any sign or semblance of dirt , or dust , or mud , or uncleanliness of any kind , it is Horta , it is Fayal .
Parsing [sent. 563 len. 33]: The lower classes of the people , in their persons and their domiciles , are not clean -- but there it stops -- the town and the island are miracles of cleanliness .
Parsing [sent. 564 len. 47]: We arrived home again finally , after a ten-mile excursion , and the irrepressible muleteers scampered at our heels through the main street , goading the donkeys , shouting the everlasting `` Sekki-yah , '' and singing `` John Brown 's Body '' in ruinous English .
Parsing [sent. 565 len. 28]: When we were dismounted and it came to settling , the shouting and jawing and swearing and quarreling among the muleteers and with us was nearly deafening .
Parsing [sent. 566 len. 73]: One fellow would demand a dollar an hour for the use of his donkey ; another claimed half a dollar for pricking him up , another a quarter for helping in that service , and about fourteen guides presented bills for showing us the way through the town and its environs ; and every vagrant of them was more vociferous , and more vehement and more frantic in gesture than his neighbor .
Parsing [sent. 567 len. 13]: We paid one guide and paid for one muleteer to each donkey .
Parsing [sent. 568 len. 11]: The mountains on some of the islands are very high .
Parsing [sent. 569 len. 50]: We sailed along the shore of the island of Pico , under a stately green pyramid that rose up with one unbroken sweep from our very feet to an altitude of 7,613 feet , and thrust its summit above the white clouds like an island adrift in a fog !

Parsing [sent. 572 len. 10]: I am not here to write Patent Office reports .
Parsing [sent. 573 len. 21]: We are on our way to Gibraltar , and shall reach there five or six days out from the Azores .
Parsing [sent. 574 len. 3]: CHAPTER VII .
Parsing [sent. 575 len. 78]: A week of buffeting a tempestuous and relentless sea ; a week of seasickness and deserted cabins ; of lonely quarterdecks drenched with spray -- spray so ambitious that it even coated the smokestacks thick with a white crust of salt to their very tops ; a week of shivering in the shelter of the lifeboats and deckhouses by day and blowing suffocating `` clouds '' and boisterously performing at dominoes in the smoking room at night .
Parsing [sent. 576 len. 13]: And the last night of the seven was the stormiest of all .
Parsing [sent. 577 len. 33]: There was no thunder , no noise but the pounding bows of the ship , the keen whistling of the gale through the cordage , and the rush of the seething waters .
Parsing [sent. 578 len. 32]: But the vessel climbed aloft as if she would climb to heaven -- then paused an instant that seemed a century and plunged headlong down again , as from a precipice .
Parsing [sent. 579 len. 9]: The sheeted sprays drenched the decks like rain .
Parsing [sent. 580 len. 7]: The blackness of darkness was everywhere .
Parsing [sent. 581 len. 48]: At long intervals a flash of lightning clove it with a quivering line of fire that revealed a heaving world of water where was nothing before , kindled the dusky cordage to glittering silver , and lit up the faces of the men with a ghastly luster !
Parsing [sent. 582 len. 17]: Fear drove many on deck that were used to avoiding the night winds and the spray .
Parsing [sent. 583 len. 58]: Some thought the vessel could not live through the night , and it seemed less dreadful to stand out in the midst of the wild tempest and see the peril that threatened than to be shut up in the sepulchral cabins , under the dim lamps , and imagine the horrors that were abroad on the ocean .
Parsing [sent. 584 len. 62]: And once out -- once where they could see the ship struggling in the strong grasp of the storm -- once where they could hear the shriek of the winds and face the driving spray and look out upon the majestic picture the lightnings disclosed , they were prisoners to a fierce fascination they could not resist , and so remained .
Parsing [sent. 585 len. 14]: It was a wild night -- and a very , very long one .
Parsing [sent. 586 len. 28]: Everybody was sent scampering to the deck at seven o'clock this lovely morning of the thirtieth of June with the glad news that land was in sight !
Parsing [sent. 587 len. 44]: It was a rare thing and a joyful , to see all the ship 's family abroad once more , albeit the happiness that sat upon every countenance could only partly conceal the ravages which that long siege of storms had wrought there .
Parsing [sent. 588 len. 32]: But dull eyes soon sparkled with pleasure , pallid cheeks flushed again , and frames weakened by sickness gathered new life from the quickening influences of the bright , fresh morning .

Parsing [sent. 1191 len. 6]: So far , so well .
Parsing [sent. 1192 len. 118]: But then the conductor locks you in when the train starts ; there is no water to drink in the car ; there is no heating apparatus for night travel ; if a drunken rowdy should get in , you could not remove a matter of twenty seats from him or enter another car ; but above all , if you are worn out and must sleep , you must sit up and do it in naps , with cramped legs and in a torturing misery that leaves you withered and lifeless the next day -- for behold they have not that culmination of all charity and human kindness , a sleeping car , in all France .

Parsing [sent. 1459 len. 263]: Surrounded by shouting thousands , by military pomp , by the splendors of his capital city , and companioned by kings and princes -- this is the man who was sneered at and reviled and called Bastard -- yet who was dreaming of a crown and an empire all the while ; who was driven into exile -- but carried his dreams with him ; who associated with the common herd in America and ran foot races for a wager -- but still sat upon a throne in fancy ; who braved every danger to go to his dying mother -- and grieved that she could not be spared to see him cast aside his plebeian vestments for the purple of royalty ; who kept his faithful watch and walked his weary beat a common policeman of London -- but dreamed the while of a coming night when he should tread the long-drawn corridors of the Tuileries ; who made the miserable fiasco of Strasbourg ; saw his poor , shabby eagle , forgetful of its lesson , refuse to perch upon his shoulder ; delivered his carefully prepared , sententious burst of eloquence upon unsympathetic ears ; found himself a prisoner , the butt of small wits , a mark for the pitiless ridicule of all the world -- yet went on dreaming of coronations and splendid pageants as before ; who lay a forgotten captive in the dungeons of Ham -- and still schemed and planned and pondered over future glory and future power ; President of France at last !

Parsing [sent. 1464 len. 12]: ABDUL-AZIZ , Sultan of Turkey , Lord of the Ottoman Empire !
Parsing [sent. 1465 len. 292]: Born to a throne ; weak , stupid , ignorant , almost , as his meanest slave ; chief of a vast royalty , yet the puppet of his Premier and the obedient child of a tyrannical mother ; a man who sits upon a throne -- the beck of whose finger moves navies and armies -- who holds in his hands the power of life and death over millions -- yet who sleeps , sleeps , eats , eats , idles with his eight hundred concubines , and when he is surfeited with eating and sleeping and idling , and would rouse up and take the reins of government and threaten to be a sultan , is charmed from his purpose by wary Fuad Pacha with a pretty plan for a new palace or a new ship -- charmed away with a new toy , like any other restless child ; a man who sees his people robbed and oppressed by soulless tax-gatherers , but speaks no word to save them ; who believes in gnomes and genii and the wild fables of The Arabian Nights , but has small regard for the mighty magicians of to-day , and is nervous in the presence of their mysterious railroads and steamboats and telegraphs ; who would see undone in Egypt all that great Mehemet Ali achieved , and would prefer rather to forget than emulate him ; a man who found his great empire a blot upon the earth -- a degraded , poverty-stricken , miserable , infamous agglomeration of ignorance , crime , and brutality -- and will idle away the allotted days of his trivial life and then pass to the dust and the worms and leave it so !

Parsing [sent. 1548 len. 96]: A handsome girl in the set before me tripped forward lightly to meet the opposite gentleman , tripped back again , grasped her dresses vigorously on both sides with her hands , raised them pretty high , danced an extraordinary jig that had more activity and exposure about it than any jig I ever saw before , and then , drawing her clothes still higher , she advanced gaily to the center and launched a vicious kick full at her vis-a-vis that must infallibly have removed his nose if he had been seven feet high .

Parsing [sent. 1551 len. 47]: The idea of it is to dance as wildly , as noisily , as furiously as you can ; expose yourself as much as possible if you are a woman ; and kick as high as you can , no matter which sex you belong to .

Parsing [sent. 1765 len. 52]: I will conclude this chapter with a remark that I am sincerely proud to be able to make -- and glad , as well , that my comrades cordially endorse it , to wit : by far the handsomest women we have seen in France were born and reared in America .
Parsing [sent. 1766 len. 31]: I feel now like a man who has redeemed a failing reputation and shed luster upon a dimmed escutcheon , by a single just deed done at the eleventh hour .
Parsing [sent. 1767 len. 9]: Let the curtain fall , to slow music .
Parsing [sent. 1768 len. 3]: CHAPTER XVI .
Parsing [sent. 1769 len. 2]: VERSAILLES !
Parsing [sent. 1770 len. 5]: It is wonderfully beautiful !
Parsing [sent. 1771 len. 57]: You gaze and stare and try to understand that it is real , that it is on the earth , that it is not the Garden of Eden -- but your brain grows giddy , stupefied by the world of beauty around you , and you half believe you are the dupe of an exquisite dream .
Parsing [sent. 1772 len. 8]: The scene thrills one like military music !
Parsing [sent. 1773 len. 188]: A noble palace , stretching its ornamented front , block upon block away , till it seemed that it would never end ; a grand promenade before it , whereon the armies of an empire might parade ; all about it rainbows of flowers , and colossal statues that were almost numberless and yet seemed only scattered over the ample space ; broad flights of stone steps leading down from the promenade to lower grounds of the park -- stairways that whole regiments might stand to arms upon and have room to spare ; vast fountains whose great bronze effigies discharged rivers of sparkling water into the air and mingled a hundred curving jets together in forms of matchless beauty ; wide grass-carpeted avenues that branched hither and thither in every direction and wandered to seemingly interminable distances , walled all the way on either side with compact ranks of leafy trees whose branches met above and formed arches as faultless and as symmetrical as ever were carved in stone ; and here and there were glimpses of sylvan lakes with miniature ships glassed in their surfaces .
Parsing [sent. 1774 len. 66]: And every where -- on the palace steps , and the great promenade , around the fountains , among the trees , and far under the arches of the endless avenues -- hundreds and hundreds of people in gay costumes walked or ran or danced , and gave to the fairy picture the life and animation which was all of perfection it could have lacked .
Parsing [sent. 1775 len. 8]: It was worth a pilgrimage to see .
Parsing [sent. 1776 len. 8]: Everything is on so gigantic a scale .
Parsing [sent. 1777 len. 8]: Nothing is small -- nothing is cheap .
Parsing [sent. 1778 len. 23]: The statues are all large ; the palace is grand ; the park covers a fair-sized county ; the avenues are interminable .
Parsing [sent. 1779 len. 12]: All the distances and all the dimensions about Versailles are vast .
Parsing [sent. 1780 len. 36]: I used to think the pictures exaggerated these distances and these dimensions beyond all reason , and that they made Versailles more beautiful than it was possible for any place in the world to be .
Parsing [sent. 1781 len. 33]: I know now that the pictures never came up to the subject in any respect , and that no painter could represent Versailles on canvas as beautiful as it is in reality .
Parsing [sent. 1782 len. 37]: I used to abuse Louis XIV for spending two hundred millions of dollars in creating this marvelous park , when bread was so scarce with some of his subjects ; but I have forgiven him now .
Parsing [sent. 1783 len. 30]: He took a tract of land sixty miles in circumference and set to work to make this park and build this palace and a road to it from Paris .
Parsing [sent. 1784 len. 29]: He kept 36,000 men employed daily on it , and the labor was so unhealthy that they used to die and be hauled off by cartloads every night .
Parsing [sent. 1785 len. 40]: The wife of a nobleman of the time speaks of this as an `` inconvenience , '' but naively remarks that `` it does not seem worthy of attention in the happy state of tranquillity we now enjoy . ''
Parsing [sent. 1786 len. 44]: I always thought ill of people at home who trimmed their shrubbery into pyramids and squares and spires and all manner of unnatural shapes , and when I saw the same thing being practiced in this great park I began to feel dissatisfied .
Parsing [sent. 1787 len. 15]: But I soon saw the idea of the thing and the wisdom of it .
Parsing [sent. 1788 len. 6]: They seek the general effect .
Parsing [sent. 1789 len. 28]: We distort a dozen sickly trees into unaccustomed shapes in a little yard no bigger than a dining room , and then surely they look absurd enough .
Parsing [sent. 1790 len. 71]: But here they take two hundred thousand tall forest trees and set them in a double row ; allow no sign of leaf or branch to grow on the trunk lower down than six feet above the ground ; from that point the boughs begin to project , and very gradually they extend outward further and further till they meet overhead , and a faultless tunnel of foliage is formed .
Parsing [sent. 1791 len. 6]: The arch is mathematically precise .
Parsing [sent. 1792 len. 7]: The effect is then very fine .
Parsing [sent. 1793 len. 19]: They make trees take fifty different shapes , and so these quaint effects are infinitely varied and picturesque .
Parsing [sent. 1794 len. 26]: The trees in no two avenues are shaped alike , and consequently the eye is not fatigued with anything in the nature of monotonous uniformity .
Parsing [sent. 1795 len. 129]: I will drop this subject now , leaving it to others to determine how these people manage to make endless ranks of lofty forest trees grow to just a certain thickness of trunk -LRB- say a foot and two-thirds -RRB- ; how they make them spring to precisely the same height for miles ; how they make them grow so close together ; how they compel one huge limb to spring from the same identical spot on each tree and form the main sweep of the arch ; and how all these things are kept exactly in the same condition and in the same exquisite shapeliness and symmetry month after month and year after year -- for I have tried to reason out the problem and have failed .
Parsing [sent. 1796 len. 44]: We walked through the great hall of sculpture and the one hundred and fifty galleries of paintings in the palace of Versailles , and felt that to be in such a place was useless unless one had a whole year at his disposal .
Parsing [sent. 1797 len. 24]: These pictures are all battle scenes , and only one solitary little canvas among them all treats of anything but great French victories .
Parsing [sent. 1798 len. 48]: We wandered , also , through the Grand Trianon and the Petit Trianon , those monuments of royal prodigality , and with histories so mournful -- filled , as it is , with souvenirs of Napoleon the First , and three dead kings and as many queens .
Parsing [sent. 1799 len. 18]: In one sumptuous bed they had all slept in succession , but no one occupies it now .
Parsing [sent. 1800 len. 60]: In a large dining room stood the table at which Louis XIV and his mistress Madame Maintenon , and after them Louis XV , and Pompadour , had sat at their meals naked and unattended -- for the table stood upon a trapdoor , which descended with it to regions below when it was necessary to replenish its dishes .
Parsing [sent. 1801 len. 35]: In a room of the Petit Trianon stood the furniture , just as poor Marie Antoinette left it when the mob came and dragged her and the King to Paris , never to return .
Parsing [sent. 1802 len. 48]: Near at hand , in the stables , were prodigious carriages that showed no color but gold -- carriages used by former kings of France on state occasions , and never used now save when a kingly head is to be crowned or an imperial infant christened .
Parsing [sent. 1803 len. 41]: And with them were some curious sleighs , whose bodies were shaped like lions , swans , tigers , etc. -- vehicles that had once been handsome with pictured designs and fine workmanship , but were dusty and decaying now .
Parsing [sent. 1804 len. 5]: They had their history .
Parsing [sent. 1805 len. 33]: When Louis XIV had finished the Grand Trianon , he told Maintenon he had created a Paradise for her , and asked if she could think of anything now to wish for .
Parsing [sent. 1806 len. 13]: He said he wished the Trianon to be perfection -- nothing less .
Parsing [sent. 1807 len. 35]: She said she could think of but one thing -- it was summer , and it was balmy France -- yet she would like well to sleigh ride in the leafy avenues of Versailles !
Parsing [sent. 1808 len. 44]: The next morning found miles and miles of grassy avenues spread thick with snowy salt and sugar , and a procession of those quaint sleighs waiting to receive the chief concubine of the gaiest and most unprincipled court that France has ever seen !
Parsing [sent. 1809 len. 33]: From sumptuous Versailles , with its palaces , its statues , its gardens , and its fountains , we journeyed back to Paris and sought its antipodes -- the Faubourg St. Antoine .
Parsing [sent. 1810 len. 97]: Little , narrow streets ; dirty children blockading them ; greasy , slovenly women capturing and spanking them ; filthy dens on first floors , with rag stores in them -LRB- the heaviest business in the Faubourg is the chiffonier 's -RRB- ; other filthy dens where whole suits of second and third-hand clothing are sold at prices that would ruin any proprietor who did not steal his stock ; still other filthy dens where they sold groceries -- sold them by the half-pennyworth -- five dollars would buy the man out , goodwill and all .
Parsing [sent. 1811 len. 21]: Up these little crooked streets they will murder a man for seven dollars and dump the body in the Seine .
Parsing [sent. 1812 len. 19]: And up some other of these streets -- most of them , I should say -- live lorettes .
Parsing [sent. 1813 len. 34]: All through this Faubourg St. Antoine , misery , poverty , vice , and crime go hand in hand , and the evidences of it stare one in the face from every side .
Parsing [sent. 1814 len. 9]: Here the people live who begin the revolutions .
Parsing [sent. 1815 len. 16]: Whenever there is anything of that kind to be done , they are always ready .
Parsing [sent. 1816 len. 25]: They take as much genuine pleasure in building a barricade as they do in cutting a throat or shoving a friend into the Seine .
Parsing [sent. 1817 len. 29]: It is these savage-looking ruffians who storm the splendid halls of the Tuileries occasionally , and swarm into Versailles when a king is to be called to account .
Parsing [sent. 1818 len. 19]: But they will build no more barricades , they will break no more soldiers ' heads with paving-stones .
Parsing [sent. 1819 len. 9]: Louis Napoleon has taken care of all that .
Parsing [sent. 1820 len. 62]: He is annihilating the crooked streets and building in their stead noble boulevards as straight as an arrow -- avenues which a cannon ball could traverse from end to end without meeting an obstruction more irresistible than the flesh and bones of men -- boulevards whose stately edifices will never afford refuges and plotting places for starving , discontented revolution breeders .
Parsing [sent. 1821 len. 25]: Five of these great thoroughfares radiate from one ample centre -- a centre which is exceedingly well adapted to the accommodation of heavy artillery .
Parsing [sent. 1822 len. 16]: The mobs used to riot there , but they must seek another rallying-place in future .
Parsing [sent. 1823 len. 22]: And this ingenious Napoleon paves the streets of his great cities with a smooth , compact composition of asphaltum and sand .
Parsing [sent. 1824 len. 16]: No more barricades of flagstones -- no more assaulting his Majesty 's troops with cobbles .
Parsing [sent. 1825 len. 25]: I can not feel friendly toward my quondam fellow-American , Napoleon III. , especially at this time , -- -LSB- July , 1867 . -RSB-
Parsing [sent. 1826 len. 53]: -- when in fancy I see his credulous victim , Maximilian , lying stark and stiff in Mexico , and his maniac widow watching eagerly from her French asylum for the form that will never come -- but I do admire his nerve , his calm self-reliance , his shrewd good sense .
Parsing [sent. 1827 len. 3]: CHAPTER XVII .
Parsing [sent. 1828 len. 10]: We had a pleasant journey of it seaward again .
Parsing [sent. 1829 len. 18]: We found that for the three past nights our ship had been in a state of war .
Parsing [sent. 1830 len. 29]: The first night the sailors of a British ship , being happy with grog , came down on the pier and challenged our sailors to a free fight .
Parsing [sent. 1831 len. 20]: They accepted with alacrity , repaired to the pier , and gained -- their share of a drawn battle .
Parsing [sent. 1832 len. 21]: Several bruised and bloody members of both parties were carried off by the police and imprisoned until the following morning .
Parsing [sent. 1833 len. 29]: The next night the British boys came again to renew the fight , but our men had had strict orders to remain on board and out of sight .
Parsing [sent. 1834 len. 33]: They did so , and the besieging party grew noisy and more and more abusive as the fact became apparent -LRB- to them -RRB- that our men were afraid to come out .
Parsing [sent. 1835 len. 14]: They went away finally with a closing burst of ridicule and offensive epithets .
Parsing [sent. 1836 len. 13]: The third night they came again and were more obstreperous than ever .
Parsing [sent. 1837 len. 23]: They swaggered up and down the almost deserted pier , and hurled curses , obscenity , and stinging sarcasms at our crew .
Parsing [sent. 1838 len. 9]: It was more than human nature could bear .
Parsing [sent. 1839 len. 14]: The executive officer ordered our men ashore -- with instructions not to fight .
Parsing [sent. 1840 len. 10]: They charged the British and gained a brilliant victory .
Parsing [sent. 1841 len. 13]: I probably would not have mentioned this war had it ended differently .
Parsing [sent. 1842 len. 22]: But I travel to learn , and I still remember that they picture no French defeats in the battle-galleries of Versailles .
Parsing [sent. 1843 len. 23]: It was like home to us to step on board the comfortable ship again and smoke and lounge about her breezy decks .
Parsing [sent. 1844 len. 21]: And yet it was not altogether like home , either , because so many members of the family were away .
Parsing [sent. 1845 len. 30]: We missed some pleasant faces which we would rather have found at dinner , and at night there were gaps in the euchre-parties which could not be satisfactorily filled .
Parsing [sent. 1846 len. 15]: `` Moult '' was in England , Jack in Switzerland , Charley in Spain .
Parsing [sent. 1847 len. 9]: Blucher was gone , none could tell where .
Parsing [sent. 1848 len. 27]: But we were at sea again , and we had the stars and the ocean to look at , and plenty of room to meditate in .
Parsing [sent. 1849 len. 47]: In due time the shores of Italy were sighted , and as we stood gazing from the decks , early in the bright summer morning , the stately city of Genoa rose up out of the sea and flung back the sunlight from her hundred palaces .
Parsing [sent. 1850 len. 38]: Here we rest for the present -- or rather , here we have been trying to rest , for some little time , but we run about too much to accomplish a great deal in that line .
Parsing [sent. 1851 len. 7]: I would like to remain here .
Parsing [sent. 1852 len. 8]: I had rather not go any further .
Parsing [sent. 1853 len. 13]: There may be prettier women in Europe , but I doubt it .
Parsing [sent. 1854 len. 26]: The population of Genoa is 120,000 ; two-thirds of these are women , I think , and at least two-thirds of the women are beautiful .
Parsing [sent. 1855 len. 19]: They are as dressy and as tasteful and as graceful as they could possibly be without being angels .
Parsing [sent. 1856 len. 11]: However , angels are not very dressy , I believe .
Parsing [sent. 1857 len. 15]: At least the angels in pictures are not -- they wear nothing but wings .
Parsing [sent. 1858 len. 9]: But these Genoese women do look so charming .
Parsing [sent. 1859 len. 25]: Most of the young demoiselles are robed in a cloud of white from head to foot , though many trick themselves out more elaborately .
Parsing [sent. 1860 len. 25]: Nine-tenths of them wear nothing on their heads but a filmy sort of veil , which falls down their backs like a white mist .
Parsing [sent. 1861 len. 25]: They are very fair , and many of them have blue eyes , but black and dreamy dark brown ones are met with oftenest .
Parsing [sent. 1862 len. 51]: The ladies and gentlemen of Genoa have a pleasant fashion of promenading in a large park on the top of a hill in the center of the city , from six till nine in the evening , and then eating ices in a neighboring garden an hour or two longer .
Parsing [sent. 1863 len. 9]: We went to the park on Sunday evening .
Parsing [sent. 1864 len. 12]: Two thousand persons were present , chiefly young ladies and gentlemen .
Parsing [sent. 1865 len. 26]: The gentlemen were dressed in the very latest Paris fashions , and the robes of the ladies glinted among the trees like so many snowflakes .
Parsing [sent. 1866 len. 13]: The multitude moved round and round the park in a great procession .
Parsing [sent. 1867 len. 32]: The bands played , and so did the fountains ; the moon and the gas lamps lit up the scene , and altogether it was a brilliant and an animated picture .
Parsing [sent. 1868 len. 18]: I scanned every female face that passed , and it seemed to me that all were handsome .
Parsing [sent. 1869 len. 10]: I never saw such a freshet of loveliness before .
Parsing [sent. 1870 len. 35]: I did not see how a man of only ordinary decision of character could marry here , because before he could get his mind made up he would fall in love with somebody else .
Parsing [sent. 1871 len. 6]: Never smoke any Italian tobacco .
Parsing [sent. 1872 len. 7]: Never do it on any account .
Parsing [sent. 1873 len. 13]: It makes me shudder to think what it must be made of .
Parsing [sent. 1874 len. 24]: You can not throw an old cigar `` stub '' down anywhere , but some vagabond will pounce upon it on the instant .
Parsing [sent. 1875 len. 41]: I like to smoke a good deal , but it wounds my sensibilities to see one of these stub-hunters watching me out of the corners of his hungry eyes and calculating how long my cigar will be likely to last .
Parsing [sent. 1876 len. 27]: It reminded me too painfully of that San Francisco undertaker who used to go to sick-beds with his watch in his hand and time the corpse .
Parsing [sent. 1877 len. 24]: One of these stub-hunters followed us all over the park last night , and we never had a smoke that was worth anything .
Parsing [sent. 1878 len. 24]: We were always moved to appease him with the stub before the cigar was half gone , because he looked so viciously anxious .
Parsing [sent. 1879 len. 32]: He regarded us as his own legitimate prey , by right of discovery , I think , because he drove off several other professionals who wanted to take stock in us .
Parsing [sent. 1880 len. 19]: Now , they surely must chew up those old stubs , and dry and sell them for smoking-tobacco .
Parsing [sent. 1881 len. 14]: Therefore , give your custom to other than Italian brands of the article .
Parsing [sent. 1882 len. 20]: `` The Superb '' and the `` City of Palaces '' are names which Genoa has held for centuries .
Parsing [sent. 1883 len. 29]: She is full of palaces , certainly , and the palaces are sumptuous inside , but they are very rusty without and make no pretensions to architectural magnificence .
Parsing [sent. 1884 len. 17]: `` Genoa the Superb '' would be a felicitous title if it referred to the women .
Parsing [sent. 1885 len. 96]: We have visited several of the palaces -- immense thick-walled piles , with great stone staircases , tesselated marble pavements on the floors , -LRB- sometimes they make a mosaic work , of intricate designs , wrought in pebbles or little fragments of marble laid in cement , -RRB- and grand salons hung with pictures by Rubens , Guido , Titian , Paul Veronese , and so on , and portraits of heads of the family , in plumed helmets and gallant coats of mail , and patrician ladies in stunning costumes of centuries ago .
Parsing [sent. 1886 len. 90]: But , of course , the folks were all out in the country for the summer , and might not have known enough to ask us to dinner if they had been at home , and so all the grand empty salons , with their resounding pavements , their grim pictures of dead ancestors , and tattered banners with the dust of bygone centuries upon them , seemed to brood solemnly of death and the grave , and our spirits ebbed away , and our cheerfulness passed from us .
Parsing [sent. 1887 len. 9]: We never went up to the eleventh story .
Parsing [sent. 1888 len. 7]: We always began to suspect ghosts .
Parsing [sent. 1889 len. 70]: There was always an undertaker-looking servant along , too , who handed us a program , pointed to the picture that began the list of the salon he was in , and then stood stiff and stark and unsmiling in his petrified livery till we were ready to move on to the next chamber , whereupon he marched sadly ahead and took up another malignantly respectful position as before .
Parsing [sent. 1890 len. 29]: I wasted so much time praying that the roof would fall in on these dispiriting flunkies that I had but little left to bestow upon palace and pictures .
Parsing [sent. 1891 len. 12]: And besides , as in Paris , we had a guide .
Parsing [sent. 1892 len. 6]: Perdition catch all the guides .
Parsing [sent. 1893 len. 36]: This one said he was the most gifted linguist in Genoa , as far as English was concerned , and that only two persons in the city beside himself could talk the language at all .
Parsing [sent. 1894 len. 39]: He showed us the birthplace of Christopher Columbus , and after we had reflected in silent awe before it for fifteen minutes , he said it was not the birthplace of Columbus , but of Columbus ' grandmother !
Parsing [sent. 1895 len. 19]: When we demanded an explanation of his conduct he only shrugged his shoulders and answered in barbarous Italian .
Parsing [sent. 1896 len. 12]: I shall speak further of this guide in a future chapter .
Parsing [sent. 1897 len. 21]: All the information we got out of him we shall be able to carry along with us , I think .
Parsing [sent. 1898 len. 21]: I have not been to church so often in a long time as I have in the last few weeks .
Parsing [sent. 1899 len. 13]: The people in these old lands seem to make churches their specialty .
Parsing [sent. 1900 len. 14]: Especially does this seem to be the case with the citizens of Genoa .
Parsing [sent. 1901 len. 16]: I think there is a church every three or four hundred yards all over town .
Parsing [sent. 1902 len. 31]: The streets are sprinkled from end to end with shovel-hatted , long-robed , well-fed priests , and the church bells by dozens are pealing all the day long , nearly .
Parsing [sent. 1903 len. 37]: Every now and then one comes across a friar of orders gray , with shaven head , long , coarse robe , rope girdle and beads , and with feet cased in sandals or entirely bare .
Parsing [sent. 1904 len. 23]: These worthies suffer in the flesh and do penance all their lives , I suppose , but they look like consummate famine-breeders .
Parsing [sent. 1905 len. 7]: They are all fat and serene .
Parsing [sent. 1906 len. 19]: The old Cathedral of San Lorenzo is about as notable a building as we have found in Genoa .
Parsing [sent. 1907 len. 33]: It is vast , and has colonnades of noble pillars , and a great organ , and the customary pomp of gilded moldings , pictures , frescoed ceilings , and so forth .
Parsing [sent. 1908 len. 20]: I can not describe it , of course -- it would require a good many pages to do that .
Parsing [sent. 1909 len. 7]: But it is a curious place .
Parsing [sent. 1910 len. 40]: They said that half of it -- from the front door halfway down to the altar -- was a Jewish synagogue before the Saviour was born , and that no alteration had been made in it since that time .
Parsing [sent. 1911 len. 10]: We doubted the statement , but did it reluctantly .
Parsing [sent. 1912 len. 8]: We would much rather have believed it .
Parsing [sent. 1913 len. 12]: The place looked in too perfect repair to be so ancient .
Parsing [sent. 1914 len. 18]: The main point of interest about the cathedral is the little Chapel of St. John the Baptist .
Parsing [sent. 1915 len. 39]: They only allow women to enter it on one day in the year , on account of the animosity they still cherish against the sex because of the murder of the Saint to gratify a caprice of Herodias .
Parsing [sent. 1916 len. 44]: In this Chapel is a marble chest , in which , they told us , were the ashes of St. John ; and around it was wound a chain , which , they said , had confined him when he was in prison .
Parsing [sent. 1917 len. 52]: We did not desire to disbelieve these statements , and yet we could not feel certain that they were correct -- partly because we could have broken that chain , and so could St. John , and partly because we had seen St. John 's ashes before , in another church .
Parsing [sent. 1918 len. 15]: We could not bring ourselves to think St. John had two sets of ashes .
Parsing [sent. 1919 len. 34]: They also showed us a portrait of the Madonna which was painted by St. Luke , and it did not look half as old and smoky as some of the pictures by Rubens .
Parsing [sent. 1920 len. 21]: We could not help admiring the Apostle 's modesty in never once mentioning in his writings that he could paint .
Parsing [sent. 1921 len. 10]: But is n't this relic matter a little overdone ?
Parsing [sent. 1922 len. 26]: We find a piece of the true cross in every old church we go into , and some of the nails that held it together .
Parsing [sent. 1923 len. 23]: I would not like to be positive , but I think we have seen as much as a keg of these nails .
Parsing [sent. 1924 len. 29]: Then there is the crown of thorns ; they have part of one in Sainte Chapelle , in Paris , and part of one also in Notre Dame .
Parsing [sent. 1925 len. 23]: And as for bones of St. Denis , I feel certain we have seen enough of them to duplicate him if necessary .
Parsing [sent. 1926 len. 17]: I only meant to write about the churches , but I keep wandering from the subject .
Parsing [sent. 1927 len. 48]: I could say that the Church of the Annunciation is a wilderness of beautiful columns , of statues , gilded moldings , and pictures almost countless , but that would give no one an entirely perfect idea of the thing , and so where is the use ?
Parsing [sent. 1928 len. 13]: One family built the whole edifice , and have got money left .
Parsing [sent. 1929 len. 7]: There is where the mystery lies .
Parsing [sent. 1930 len. 16]: We had an idea at first that only a mint could have survived the expense .
Parsing [sent. 1931 len. 20]: These people here live in the heaviest , highest , broadest , darkest , solidest houses one can imagine .
Parsing [sent. 1932 len. 11]: Each one might `` laugh a siege to scorn . ''
Parsing [sent. 1933 len. 31]: A hundred feet front and a hundred high is about the style , and you go up three flights of stairs before you begin to come upon signs of occupancy .
Parsing [sent. 1934 len. 20]: Everything is stone , and stone of the heaviest -- floors , stairways , mantels , benches -- everything .
Parsing [sent. 1935 len. 9]: The walls are four to five feet thick .
Parsing [sent. 1936 len. 18]: The streets generally are four or five to eight feet wide and as crooked as a corkscrew .
Parsing [sent. 1937 len. 45]: You go along one of these gloomy cracks , and look up and behold the sky like a mere ribbon of light , far above your head , where the tops of the tall houses on either side of the street bend almost together .
Parsing [sent. 1938 len. 22]: You feel as if you were at the bottom of some tremendous abyss , with all the world far above you .
Parsing [sent. 1939 len. 35]: You wind in and out and here and there , in the most mysterious way , and have no more idea of the points of the compass than if you were a blind man .
Parsing [sent. 1940 len. 60]: You can never persuade yourself that these are actually streets , and the frowning , dingy , monstrous houses dwellings , till you see one of these beautiful , prettily dressed women emerge from them -- see her emerge from a dark , dreary-looking den that looks dungeon all over , from the ground away halfway up to heaven .
Parsing [sent. 1941 len. 19]: And then you wonder that such a charming moth could come from such a forbidding shell as that .
Parsing [sent. 1942 len. 28]: The streets are wisely made narrow and the houses heavy and thick and stony , in order that the people may be cool in this roasting climate .
Parsing [sent. 1943 len. 9]: And they are cool , and stay so .
Parsing [sent. 1944 len. 43]: And while I think of it -- the men wear hats and have very dark complexions , but the women wear no headgear but a flimsy veil like a gossamer 's web , and yet are exceedingly fair as a general thing .
Parsing [sent. 1945 len. 6]: Singular , is n't it ?
Parsing [sent. 1946 len. 26]: The huge palaces of Genoa are each supposed to be occupied by one family , but they could accommodate a hundred , I should think .
Parsing [sent. 1947 len. 27]: They are relics of the grandeur of Genoa 's palmy days -- the days when she was a great commercial and maritime power several centuries ago .
Parsing [sent. 1948 len. 48]: These houses , solid marble palaces though they be , are in many cases of a dull pinkish color , outside , and from pavement to eaves are pictured with Genoese battle scenes , with monstrous Jupiters and Cupids , and with familiar illustrations from Grecian mythology .
Parsing [sent. 1949 len. 24]: Where the paint has yielded to age and exposure and is peeling off in flakes and patches , the effect is not happy .
Parsing [sent. 1950 len. 28]: A noseless Cupid or a Jupiter with an eye out or a Venus with a fly-blister on her breast , are not attractive features in a picture .
Parsing [sent. 1951 len. 32]: Some of these painted walls reminded me somewhat of the tall van , plastered with fanciful bills and posters , that follows the bandwagon of a circus about a country village .
Parsing [sent. 1952 len. 23]: I have not read or heard that the outsides of the houses of any other European city are frescoed in this way .
Parsing [sent. 1953 len. 13]: I can not conceive of such a thing as Genoa in ruins .
Parsing [sent. 1954 len. 53]: Such massive arches , such ponderous substructions as support these towering broad-winged edifices , we have seldom seen before ; and surely the great blocks of stone of which these edifices are built can never decay ; walls that are as thick as an ordinary American doorway is high can not crumble .
Parsing [sent. 1955 len. 14]: The republics of Genoa and Pisa were very powerful in the Middle Ages .
Parsing [sent. 1956 len. 18]: Their ships filled the Mediterranean , and they carried on an extensive commerce with Constantinople and Syria .
Parsing [sent. 1957 len. 21]: Their warehouses were the great distributing depots from whence the costly merchandise of the East was sent abroad over Europe .
Parsing [sent. 1958 len. 22]: They were warlike little nations and defied , in those days , governments that overshadow them now as mountains overshadow molehills .
Parsing [sent. 1959 len. 55]: The Saracens captured and pillaged Genoa nine hundred years ago , but during the following century Genoa and Pisa entered into an offensive and defensive alliance and besieged the Saracen colonies in Sardinia and the Balearic Isles with an obstinacy that maintained its pristine vigor and held to its purpose for forty long years .
Parsing [sent. 1960 len. 16]: They were victorious at last and divided their conquests equably among their great patrician families .
Parsing [sent. 1961 len. 59]: Descendants of some of those proud families still inhabit the palaces of Genoa , and trace in their own features a resemblance to the grim knights whose portraits hang in their stately halls , and to pictured beauties with pouting lips and merry eyes whose originals have been dust and ashes for many a dead and forgotten century .
Parsing [sent. 1962 len. 51]: The hotel we live in belonged to one of those great orders of knights of the Cross in the times of the Crusades , and its mailed sentinels once kept watch and ward in its massive turrets and woke the echoes of these halls and corridors with their iron heels .

Parsing [sent. 1966 len. 18]: Her smiths take silver ingots and work them up into all manner of graceful and beautiful forms .
Parsing [sent. 1967 len. 83]: They make bunches of flowers , from flakes and wires of silver , that counterfeit the delicate creations the frost weaves upon a windowpane ; and we were shown a miniature silver temple whose fluted columns , whose Corinthian capitals and rich entablatures , whose spire , statues , bells , and ornate lavishness of sculpture were wrought in polished silver , and with such matchless art that every detail was a fascinating study and the finished edifice a wonder of beauty .

Parsing [sent. 2674 len. 3]: CHAPTER XXII .
Parsing [sent. 2675 len. 75]: This Venice , which was a haughty , invincible , magnificent Republic for nearly fourteen hundred years ; whose armies compelled the world 's applause whenever and wherever they battled ; whose navies well nigh held dominion of the seas , and whose merchant fleets whitened the remotest oceans with their sails and loaded these piers with the products of every clime , is fallen a prey to poverty , neglect and melancholy decay .
Parsing [sent. 2676 len. 38]: Six hundred years ago , Venice was the Autocrat of Commerce ; her mart was the great commercial centre , the distributing-house from whence the enormous trade of the Orient was spread abroad over the Western world .
Parsing [sent. 2677 len. 26]: To-day her piers are deserted , her warehouses are empty , her merchant fleets are vanished , her armies and her navies are but memories .
Parsing [sent. 2678 len. 32]: Her glory is departed , and with her crumbling grandeur of wharves and palaces about her she sits among her stagnant lagoons , forlorn and beggared , forgotten of the world .
Parsing [sent. 2679 len. 58]: She that in her palmy days commanded the commerce of a hemisphere and made the weal or woe of nations with a beck of her puissant finger , is become the humblest among the peoples of the earth , -- a peddler of glass beads for women , and trifling toys and trinkets for school-girls and children .
Parsing [sent. 2680 len. 21]: The venerable Mother of the Republics is scarce a fit subject for flippant speech or the idle gossipping of tourists .
Parsing [sent. 2681 len. 39]: It seems a sort of sacrilege to disturb the glamour of old romance that pictures her to us softly from afar off as through a tinted mist , and curtains her ruin and her desolation from our view .
Parsing [sent. 2682 len. 50]: One ought , indeed , to turn away from her rags , her poverty and her humiliation , and think of her only as she was when she sunk the fleets of Charlemagne ; when she humbled Frederick Barbarossa or waved her victorious banners above the battlements of Constantinople .

Parsing [sent. 2737 len. 23]: This was in the old days when the Patricians alone governed Venice -- the common herd had no vote and no voice .

Parsing [sent. 2756 len. 211]: Down below the level of the water , by the light of smoking torches , we were shown the damp , thick-walled cells where many a proud patrician 's life was eaten away by the long-drawn miseries of solitary imprisonment -- without light , air , books ; naked , unshaven , uncombed , covered with vermin ; his useless tongue forgetting its office , with none to speak to ; the days and nights of his life no longer marked , but merged into one eternal eventless night ; far away from all cheerful sounds , buried in the silence of a tomb ; forgotten by his helpless friends , and his fate a dark mystery to them forever ; losing his own memory at last , and knowing no more who he was or how he came there ; devouring the loaf of bread and drinking the water that were thrust into the cell by unseen hands , and troubling his worn spirit no more with hopes and fears and doubts and longings to be free ; ceasing to scratch vain prayers and complainings on walls where none , not even himself , could see them , and resigning himself to hopeless apathy , driveling childishness , lunacy !

Parsing [sent. 2788 len. 3]: CHAPTER XXIII .
Parsing [sent. 2789 len. 18]: The Venetian gondola is as free and graceful , in its gliding movement , as a serpent .
Parsing [sent. 2790 len. 43]: It is twenty or thirty feet long , and is narrow and deep , like a canoe ; its sharp bow and stern sweep upward from the water like the horns of a crescent with the abruptness of the curve slightly modified .
Parsing [sent. 2791 len. 26]: The bow is ornamented with a steel comb with a battle-ax attachment which threatens to cut passing boats in two occasionally , but never does .
Parsing [sent. 2792 len. 39]: The gondola is painted black because in the zenith of Venetian magnificence the gondolas became too gorgeous altogether , and the Senate decreed that all such display must cease , and a solemn , unembellished black be substituted .
Parsing [sent. 2793 len. 33]: If the truth were known , it would doubtless appear that rich plebeians grew too prominent in their affectation of patrician show on the Grand Canal , and required a wholesome snubbing .
Parsing [sent. 2794 len. 22]: Reverence for the hallowed Past and its traditions keeps the dismal fashion in force now that the compulsion exists no longer .
Parsing [sent. 2795 len. 5]: So let it remain .
Parsing [sent. 2796 len. 7]: It is the color of mourning .
Parsing [sent. 2797 len. 3]: Venice mourns .
Parsing [sent. 2798 len. 14]: The stern of the boat is decked over and the gondolier stands there .
Parsing [sent. 2799 len. 19]: He uses a single oar -- a long blade , of course , for he stands nearly erect .
Parsing [sent. 2800 len. 34]: A wooden peg , a foot and a half high , with two slight crooks or curves in one side of it and one in the other , projects above the starboard gunwale .
Parsing [sent. 2801 len. 86]: Against that peg the gondolier takes a purchase with his oar , changing it at intervals to the other side of the peg or dropping it into another of the crooks , as the steering of the craft may demand -- and how in the world he can back and fill , shoot straight ahead , or flirt suddenly around a corner , and make the oar stay in those insignificant notches , is a problem to me and a never diminishing matter of interest .
Parsing [sent. 2802 len. 21]: I am afraid I study the gondolier 's marvelous skill more than I do the sculptured palaces we glide among .
Parsing [sent. 2803 len. 45]: He cuts a corner so closely , now and then , or misses another gondola by such an imperceptible hair-breadth that I feel myself `` scrooching , '' as the children say , just as one does when a buggy wheel grazes his elbow .
Parsing [sent. 2804 len. 33]: But he makes all his calculations with the nicest precision , and goes darting in and out among a Broadway confusion of busy craft with the easy confidence of the educated hackman .
Parsing [sent. 2805 len. 6]: He never makes a mistake .
Parsing [sent. 2806 len. 75]: Sometimes we go flying down the great canals at such a gait that we can get only the merest glimpses into front doors , and again , in obscure alleys in the suburbs , we put on a solemnity suited to the silence , the mildew , the stagnant waters , the clinging weeds , the deserted houses and the general lifelessness of the place , and move to the spirit of grave meditation .
Parsing [sent. 2807 len. 22]: The gondolier is a picturesque rascal for all he wears no satin harness , no plumed bonnet , no silken tights .
Parsing [sent. 2808 len. 19]: His attitude is stately ; he is lithe and supple ; all his movements are full of grace .
Parsing [sent. 2809 len. 41]: When his long canoe , and his fine figure , towering from its high perch on the stern , are cut against the evening sky , they make a picture that is very novel and striking to a foreign eye .
Parsing [sent. 2810 len. 57]: We sit in the cushioned carriage-body of a cabin , with the curtains drawn , and smoke , or read , or look out upon the passing boats , the houses , the bridges , the people , and enjoy ourselves much more than we could in a buggy jolting over our cobble-stone pavements at home .
Parsing [sent. 2811 len. 12]: This is the gentlest , pleasantest locomotion we have ever known .
Parsing [sent. 2812 len. 20]: But it seems queer -- ever so queer -- to see a boat doing duty as a private carriage .

Parsing [sent. 2822 len. 107]: We see the ladies go out shopping , in the most natural way , and flit from street to street and from store to store , just in the good old fashion , except that they leave the gondola , instead of a private carriage , waiting at the curbstone a couple of hours for them , -- waiting while they make the nice young clerks pull down tons and tons of silks and velvets and moire antiques and those things ; and then they buy a paper of pins and go paddling away to confer the rest of their disastrous patronage on some other firm .

Parsing [sent. 3295 len. 3]: CHAPTER XXVI .
Parsing [sent. 3296 len. 9]: What is it that confers the noblest delight ?
Parsing [sent. 3297 len. 22]: What is that which swells a man 's breast with pride above that which any other experience can bring to him ?
Parsing [sent. 3298 len. 2]: Discovery !
Parsing [sent. 3299 len. 32]: To know that you are walking where none others have walked ; that you are beholding what human eye has not seen before ; that you are breathing a virgin atmosphere .
Parsing [sent. 3300 len. 35]: To give birth to an idea -- to discover a great thought -- an intellectual nugget , right under the dust of a field that many a brain -- plow had gone over before .
Parsing [sent. 3301 len. 24]: To find a new planet , to invent a new hinge , to find the way to make the lightnings carry your messages .
Parsing [sent. 3302 len. 10]: To be the first -- that is the idea .
Parsing [sent. 3303 len. 39]: To do something , say something , see something , before any body else -- these are the things that confer a pleasure compared with which other pleasures are tame and commonplace , other ecstasies cheap and trivial .
Parsing [sent. 3304 len. 168]: Morse , with his first message , brought by his servant , the lightning ; Fulton , in that long-drawn century of suspense , when he placed his hand upon the throttle-valve and lo , the steamboat moved ; Jenner , when his patient with the cow 's virus in his blood , walked through the smallpox hospitals unscathed ; Howe , when the idea shot through his brain that for a hundred and twenty generations the eye had been bored through the wrong end of the needle ; the nameless lord of art who laid down his chisel in some old age that is forgotten , now , and gloated upon the finished Laocoon ; Daguerre , when he commanded the sun , riding in the zenith , to print the landscape upon his insignificant silvered plate , and he obeyed ; Columbus , in the Pinta 's shrouds , when he swung his hat above a fabled sea and gazed abroad upon an unknown world !
Parsing [sent. 3305 len. 29]: These are the men who have really lived -- who have actually comprehended what pleasure is -- who have crowded long lifetimes of ecstasy into a single moment .
Parsing [sent. 3306 len. 17]: What is there in Rome for me to see that others have not seen before me ?
Parsing [sent. 3307 len. 13]: What is there for me to touch that others have not touched ?
Parsing [sent. 3308 len. 27]: What is there for me to feel , to learn , to hear , to know , that shall thrill me before it pass to others ?
Parsing [sent. 3309 len. 5]: What can I discover ?
Parsing [sent. 3310 len. 3]: -- Nothing .
Parsing [sent. 3311 len. 3]: Nothing whatsoever .
Parsing [sent. 3312 len. 7]: One charm of travel dies here .
Parsing [sent. 3313 len. 8]: But if I were only a Roman !
Parsing [sent. 3314 len. 37]: -- If , added to my own I could be gifted with modern Roman sloth , modern Roman superstition , and modern Roman boundlessness of ignorance , what bewildering worlds of unsuspected wonders I would discover !
Parsing [sent. 3315 len. 18]: Ah , if I were only a habitant of the Campagna five and twenty miles from Rome !
Parsing [sent. 3316 len. 5]: Then I would travel .
Parsing [sent. 3317 len. 26]: I would go to America , and see , and learn , and return to the Campagna and stand before my countrymen an illustrious discoverer .
Parsing [sent. 3318 len. 23]: I would say : `` I saw there a country which has no overshadowing Mother Church , and yet the people survive .
Parsing [sent. 3319 len. 25]: I saw a government which never was protected by foreign soldiers at a cost greater than that required to carry on the government itself .
Parsing [sent. 3320 len. 42]: I saw common men and common women who could read ; I even saw small children of common country people reading from books ; if I dared think you would believe it , I would say they could write , also .
Parsing [sent. 3321 len. 43]: `` In the cities I saw people drinking a delicious beverage made of chalk and water , but never once saw goats driven through their Broadway or their Pennsylvania Avenue or their Montgomery street and milked at the doors of the houses .
Parsing [sent. 3322 len. 14]: I saw real glass windows in the houses of even the commonest people .
Parsing [sent. 3323 len. 23]: Some of the houses are not of stone , nor yet of bricks ; I solemnly swear they are made of wood .
Parsing [sent. 3324 len. 23]: Houses there will take fire and burn , sometimes -- actually burn entirely down , and not leave a single vestige behind .
Parsing [sent. 3325 len. 12]: I could state that for a truth , upon my death-bed .
Parsing [sent. 3326 len. 53]: And as a proof that the circumstance is not rare , I aver that they have a thing which they call a fire-engine , which vomits forth great streams of water , and is kept always in readiness , by night and by day , to rush to houses that are burning .
Parsing [sent. 3327 len. 36]: You would think one engine would be sufficient , but some great cities have a hundred ; they keep men hired , and pay them by the month to do nothing but put out fires .
Parsing [sent. 3328 len. 29]: For a certain sum of money other men will insure that your house shall not burn down ; and if it burns they will pay you for it .
Parsing [sent. 3329 len. 23]: There are hundreds and thousands of schools , and any body may go and learn to be wise , like a priest .
Parsing [sent. 3330 len. 26]: In that singular country if a rich man dies a sinner , he is damned ; he can not buy salvation with money for masses .
Parsing [sent. 3331 len. 12]: There is really not much use in being rich , there .
Parsing [sent. 3332 len. 85]: Not much use as far as the other world is concerned , but much , very much use , as concerns this ; because there , if a man be rich , he is very greatly honored , and can become a legislator , a governor , a general , a senator , no matter how ignorant an ass he is -- just as in our beloved Italy the nobles hold all the great places , even though sometimes they are born noble idiots .
Parsing [sent. 3333 len. 51]: There , if a man be rich , they give him costly presents , they ask him to feasts , they invite him to drink complicated beverages ; but if he be poor and in debt , they require him to do that which they term to ` settle . '
Parsing [sent. 3334 len. 56]: The women put on a different dress almost every day ; the dress is usually fine , but absurd in shape ; the very shape and fashion of it changes twice in a hundred years ; and did I but covet to be called an extravagant falsifier , I would say it changed even oftener .
Parsing [sent. 3335 len. 34]: Hair does not grow upon the American women 's heads ; it is made for them by cunning workmen in the shops , and is curled and frizzled into scandalous and ungodly forms .
Parsing [sent. 3336 len. 37]: Some persons wear eyes of glass which they see through with facility perhaps , else they would not use them ; and in the mouths of some are teeth made by the sacrilegious hand of man .
Parsing [sent. 3337 len. 9]: The dress of the men is laughably grotesque .
Parsing [sent. 3338 len. 53]: They carry no musket in ordinary life , nor no long-pointed pole ; they wear no wide green-lined cloak ; they wear no peaked black felt hat , no leathern gaiters reaching to the knee , no goat-skin breeches with the hair side out , no hob-nailed shoes , no prodigious spurs .
Parsing [sent. 3339 len. 68]: They wear a conical hat termed a ` nail-keg ; ' a coat of saddest black ; a shirt which shows dirt so easily that it has to be changed every month , and is very troublesome ; things called pantaloons , which are held up by shoulder straps , and on their feet they wear boots which are ridiculous in pattern and can stand no wear .
Parsing [sent. 3340 len. 14]: Yet dressed in this fantastic garb , these people laughed at my costume .
Parsing [sent. 3341 len. 18]: In that country , books are so common that it is really no curiosity to see one .
Parsing [sent. 3342 len. 3]: Newspapers also .
Parsing [sent. 3343 len. 14]: They have a great machine which prints such things by thousands every hour .
Parsing [sent. 3344 len. 25]: `` I saw common men , there -- men who were neither priests nor princes -- who yet absolutely owned the land they tilled .
Parsing [sent. 3345 len. 13]: It was not rented from the church , nor from the nobles .
Parsing [sent. 3346 len. 10]: I am ready to take my oath of this .
Parsing [sent. 3347 len. 25]: In that country you might fall from a third story window three several times , and not mash either a soldier or a priest .
Parsing [sent. 3348 len. 9]: -- The scarcity of such people is astonishing .
Parsing [sent. 3349 len. 22]: In the cities you will see a dozen civilians for every soldier , and as many for every priest or preacher .
Parsing [sent. 3350 len. 15]: Jews , there , are treated just like human beings , instead of dogs .
Parsing [sent. 3351 len. 215]: They can work at any business they please ; they can sell brand new goods if they want to ; they can keep drug-stores ; they can practice medicine among Christians ; they can even shake hands with Christians if they choose ; they can associate with them , just the same as one human being does with another human being ; they do n't have to stay shut up in one corner of the towns ; they can live in any part of a town they like best ; it is said they even have the privilege of buying land and houses , and owning them themselves , though I doubt that , myself ; they never have had to run races naked through the public streets , against jackasses , to please the people in carnival time ; there they never have been driven by the soldiers into a church every Sunday for hundreds of years to hear themselves and their religion especially and particularly cursed ; at this very day , in that curious country , a Jew is allowed to vote , hold office , yea , get up on a rostrum in the public street and express his opinion of the government if the government do n't suit him !
Parsing [sent. 3352 len. 6]: Ah , it is wonderful .
Parsing [sent. 3353 len. 89]: The common people there know a great deal ; they even have the effrontery to complain if they are not properly governed , and to take hold and help conduct the government themselves ; if they had laws like ours , which give one dollar of every three a crop produces to the government for taxes , they would have that law altered : instead of paying thirty-three dollars in taxes , out of every one hundred they receive , they complain if they have to pay seven .
Parsing [sent. 3354 len. 5]: They are curious people .
Parsing [sent. 3355 len. 10]: They do not know when they are well off .
Parsing [sent. 3356 len. 19]: Mendicant priests do not prowl among them with baskets begging for the church and eating up their substance .
Parsing [sent. 3357 len. 25]: One hardly ever sees a minister of the gospel going around there in his bare feet , with a basket , begging for subsistence .
Parsing [sent. 3358 len. 28]: In that country the preachers are not like our mendicant orders of friars -- they have two or three suits of clothing , and they wash sometimes .
Parsing [sent. 3359 len. 94]: In that land are mountains far higher than the Alban mountains ; the vast Roman Campagna , a hundred miles long and full forty broad , is really small compared to the United States of America ; the Tiber , that celebrated river of ours , which stretches its mighty course almost two hundred miles , and which a lad can scarcely throw a stone across at Rome , is not so long , nor yet so wide , as the American Mississippi -- nor yet the Ohio , nor even the Hudson .
Parsing [sent. 3360 len. 16]: In America the people are absolutely wiser and know much more than their grandfathers did .
Parsing [sent. 3361 len. 26]: They do not plow with a sharpened stick , nor yet with a three-cornered block of wood that merely scratches the top of the ground .
