Parsing [sent. 5284 len. 289]: That is to say , its Moslem houses are heavy and dark , and as comfortless as so many tombs ; its streets are crooked , rudely and roughly paved , and as narrow as an ordinary staircase ; the streets uniformly carry a man to any other place than the one he wants to go to , and surprise him by landing him in the most unexpected localities ; business is chiefly carried on in great covered bazaars , celled like a honeycomb with innumerable shops no larger than a common closet , and the whole hive cut up into a maze of alleys about wide enough to accommodate a laden camel , and well calculated to confuse a stranger and eventually lose him ; every where there is dirt , every where there are fleas , every where there are lean , broken-hearted dogs ; every alley is thronged with people ; wherever you look , your eye rests upon a wild masquerade of extravagant costumes ; the workshops are all open to the streets , and the workmen visible ; all manner of sounds assail the ear , and over them all rings out the muezzin 's cry from some tall minaret , calling the faithful vagabonds to prayer ; and superior to the call to prayer , the noises in the streets , the interest of the costumes -- superior to every thing , and claiming the bulk of attention first , last , and all the time -- is a combination of Mohammedan stenches , to which the smell of even a Chinese quarter would be as pleasant as the roasting odors of the fatted calf to the nostrils of the returning Prodigal .

Parsing [sent. 7212 len. 41]: There could not have been more fragments of stone strewn broadcast over this part of the world , if every ten square feet of the land had been occupied by a separate and distinct stonecutter 's establishment for an age .

Parsing [sent. 7221 len. 41]: We spurred up hill after hill , and usually began to stretch our necks minutes before we got to the top -- but disappointment always followed : -- more stupid hills beyond -- more unsightly landscape -- no Holy City .
Parsing [sent. 7222 len. 43]: At last , away in the middle of the day , ancient bite of wall and crumbling arches began to line the way -- we toiled up one more hill , and every pilgrim and every sinner swung his hat on high !
Parsing [sent. 7223 len. 2]: Jerusalem !
Parsing [sent. 7224 len. 29]: Perched on its eternal hills , white and domed and solid , massed together and hooped with high gray walls , the venerable city gleamed in the sun .
Parsing [sent. 7225 len. 3]: So small !
Parsing [sent. 7226 len. 27]: Why , it was no larger than an American village of four thousand inhabitants , and no larger than an ordinary Syrian city of thirty thousand .
Parsing [sent. 7227 len. 7]: Jerusalem numbers only fourteen thousand people .
Parsing [sent. 7228 len. 45]: We dismounted and looked , without speaking a dozen sentences , across the wide intervening valley for an hour or more ; and noted those prominent features of the city that pictures make familiar to all men from their school days till their death .
Parsing [sent. 7229 len. 59]: We could recognize the Tower of Hippicus , the Mosque of Omar , the Damascus Gate , the Mount of Olives , the Valley of Jehoshaphat , the Tower of David , and the Garden of Gethsemane -- and dating from these landmarks could tell very nearly the localities of many others we were not able to distinguish .
Parsing [sent. 7230 len. 18]: I record it here as a notable but not discreditable fact that not even our pilgrims wept .

Parsing [sent. 7234 len. 18]: The thoughts Jerusalem suggests are full of poetry , sublimity , and more than all , dignity .
Parsing [sent. 7235 len. 15]: Such thoughts do not find their appropriate expression in the emotions of the nursery .
Parsing [sent. 7236 len. 65]: Just after noon we entered these narrow , crooked streets , by the ancient and the famed Damascus Gate , and now for several hours I have been trying to comprehend that I am actually in the illustrious old city where Solomon dwelt , where Abraham held converse with the Deity , and where walls still stand that witnessed the spectacle of the Crucifixion .
Parsing [sent. 7237 len. 3]: CHAPTER LIII .
Parsing [sent. 7238 len. 20]: A fast walker could go outside the walls of Jerusalem and walk entirely around the city in an hour .
Parsing [sent. 7239 len. 15]: I do not know how else to make one understand how small it is .
Parsing [sent. 7240 len. 8]: The appearance of the city is peculiar .
Parsing [sent. 7241 len. 16]: It is as knobby with countless little domes as a prison door is with bolt-heads .
Parsing [sent. 7242 len. 37]: Every house has from one to half a dozen of these white plastered domes of stone , broad and low , sitting in the centre of , or in a cluster upon , the flat roof .
Parsing [sent. 7243 len. 55]: Wherefore , when one looks down from an eminence , upon the compact mass of houses -LRB- so closely crowded together , in fact , that there is no appearance of streets at all , and so the city looks solid , -RRB- he sees the knobbiest town in the world , except Constantinople .
Parsing [sent. 7244 len. 18]: It looks as if it might be roofed , from centre to circumference , with inverted saucers .
Parsing [sent. 7245 len. 32]: The monotony of the view is interrupted only by the great Mosque of Omar , the Tower of Hippicus , and one or two other buildings that rise into commanding prominence .
Parsing [sent. 7246 len. 32]: The houses are generally two stories high , built strongly of masonry , whitewashed or plastered outside , and have a cage of wooden lattice-work projecting in front of every window .
Parsing [sent. 7247 len. 28]: To reproduce a Jerusalem street , it would only be necessary to up-end a chicken-coop and hang it before each window in an alley of American houses .
Parsing [sent. 7248 len. 49]: The streets are roughly and badly paved with stone , and are tolerably crooked -- enough so to make each street appear to close together constantly and come to an end about a hundred yards ahead of a pilgrim as long as he chooses to walk in it .
Parsing [sent. 7249 len. 49]: Projecting from the top of the lower story of many of the houses is a very narrow porch-roof or shed , without supports from below ; and I have several times seen cats jump across the street from one shed to the other when they were out calling .
Parsing [sent. 7250 len. 12]: The cats could have jumped double the distance without extraordinary exertion .
Parsing [sent. 7251 len. 15]: I mention these things to give an idea of how narrow the streets are .
Parsing [sent. 7252 len. 27]: Since a cat can jump across them without the least inconvenience , it is hardly necessary to state that such streets are too narrow for carriages .
Parsing [sent. 7253 len. 9]: These vehicles can not navigate the Holy City .
Parsing [sent. 7254 len. 32]: The population of Jerusalem is composed of Moslems , Jews , Greeks , Latins , Armenians , Syrians , Copts , Abyssinians , Greek Catholics , and a handful of Protestants .
Parsing [sent. 7255 len. 17]: One hundred of the latter sect are all that dwell now in this birthplace of Christianity .
Parsing [sent. 7256 len. 25]: The nice shades of nationality comprised in the above list , and the languages spoken by them , are altogether too numerous to mention .
Parsing [sent. 7257 len. 28]: It seems to me that all the races and colors and tongues of the earth must be represented among the fourteen thousand souls that dwell in Jerusalem .
Parsing [sent. 7258 len. 28]: Rags , wretchedness , poverty and dirt , those signs and symbols that indicate the presence of Moslem rule more surely than the crescent-flag itself , abound .
Parsing [sent. 7259 len. 35]: Lepers , cripples , the blind , and the idiotic , assail you on every hand , and they know but one word of but one language apparently -- the eternal `` bucksheesh . ''
Parsing [sent. 7260 len. 53]: To see the numbers of maimed , malformed and diseased humanity that throng the holy places and obstruct the gates , one might suppose that the ancient days had come again , and that the angel of the Lord was expected to descend at any moment to stir the waters of Bethesda .
Parsing [sent. 7261 len. 10]: Jerusalem is mournful , and dreary , and lifeless .
Parsing [sent. 7262 len. 8]: I would not desire to live here .
Parsing [sent. 7263 len. 9]: One naturally goes first to the Holy Sepulchre .
Parsing [sent. 7264 len. 55]: It is right in the city , near the western gate ; it and the place of the Crucifixion , and , in fact , every other place intimately connected with that tremendous event , are ingeniously massed together and covered by one roof -- the dome of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre .
Parsing [sent. 7265 len. 50]: Entering the building , through the midst of the usual assemblage of beggars , one sees on his left a few Turkish guards -- for Christians of different sects will not only quarrel , but fight , also , in this sacred place , if allowed to do it .
Parsing [sent. 7266 len. 27]: Before you is a marble slab , which covers the Stone of Unction , whereon the Saviour 's body was laid to prepare it for burial .
Parsing [sent. 7267 len. 20]: It was found necessary to conceal the real stone in this way in order to save it from destruction .
Parsing [sent. 7268 len. 15]: Pilgrims were too much given to chipping off pieces of it to carry home .
Parsing [sent. 7269 len. 22]: Near by is a circular railing which marks the spot where the Virgin stood when the Lord 's body was anointed .
Parsing [sent. 7270 len. 20]: Entering the great Rotunda , we stand before the most sacred locality in Christendom -- the grave of Jesus .
Parsing [sent. 7271 len. 16]: It is in the centre of the church , and immediately under the great dome .
Parsing [sent. 7272 len. 19]: It is inclosed in a sort of little temple of yellow and white stone , of fanciful design .
Parsing [sent. 7273 len. 39]: Within the little temple is a portion of the very stone which was rolled away from the door of the Sepulchre , and on which the angel was sitting when Mary came thither `` at early dawn . ''
Parsing [sent. 7274 len. 12]: Stooping low , we enter the vault -- the Sepulchre itself .
Parsing [sent. 7275 len. 33]: It is only about six feet by seven , and the stone couch on which the dead Saviour lay extends from end to end of the apartment and occupies half its width .
Parsing [sent. 7276 len. 18]: It is covered with a marble slab which has been much worn by the lips of pilgrims .
Parsing [sent. 7277 len. 9]: This slab serves as an altar , now .
Parsing [sent. 7278 len. 31]: Over it hang some fifty gold and silver lamps , which are kept always burning , and the place is otherwise scandalized by trumpery , gewgaws , and tawdry ornamentation .
Parsing [sent. 7279 len. 36]: All sects of Christians -LRB- except Protestants , -RRB- have chapels under the roof of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre , and each must keep to itself and not venture upon another 's ground .
Parsing [sent. 7280 len. 23]: It has been proven conclusively that they can not worship together around the grave of the Saviour of the World in peace .
Parsing [sent. 7281 len. 20]: The chapel of the Syrians is not handsome ; that of the Copts is the humblest of them all .

Parsing [sent. 7283 len. 27]: In one side of it two ancient tombs are hewn , which are claimed to be those in which Nicodemus and Joseph of Aramathea were buried .
Parsing [sent. 7284 len. 60]: As we moved among the great piers and pillars of another part of the church , we came upon a party of black-robed , animal-looking Italian monks , with candles in their hands , who were chanting something in Latin , and going through some kind of religious performance around a disk of white marble let into the floor .

Parsing [sent. 7290 len. 16]: We were shown the place where our Lord appeared to His mother after the Resurrection .

Parsing [sent. 7292 len. 14]: According to the legend , this great discovery elicited extravagant demonstrations of joy .
Parsing [sent. 7293 len. 7]: But they were of short duration .
Parsing [sent. 7294 len. 18]: The question intruded itself : `` Which bore the blessed Saviour , and which the thieves ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7295 len. 26]: To be in doubt , in so mighty a matter as this -- to be uncertain which one to adore -- was a grievous misfortune .
Parsing [sent. 7296 len. 8]: It turned the public joy to sorrow .
Parsing [sent. 7297 len. 20]: But when lived there a holy priest who could not set so simple a trouble as this at rest ?
Parsing [sent. 7298 len. 15]: One of these soon hit upon a plan that would be a certain test .
Parsing [sent. 7299 len. 9]: A noble lady lay very ill in Jerusalem .
Parsing [sent. 7300 len. 18]: The wise priests ordered that the three crosses be taken to her bedside one at a time .
Parsing [sent. 7301 len. 4]: It was done .
Parsing [sent. 7302 len. 42]: When her eyes fell upon the first one , she uttered a scream that was heard beyond the Damascus Gate , and even upon the Mount of Olives , it was said , and then fell back in a deadly swoon .
Parsing [sent. 7303 len. 9]: They recovered her and brought the second cross .
Parsing [sent. 7304 len. 22]: Instantly she went into fearful convulsions , and it was with the greatest difficulty that six strong men could hold her .
Parsing [sent. 7305 len. 13]: They were afraid , now , to bring in the third cross .
Parsing [sent. 7306 len. 27]: They began to fear that possibly they had fallen upon the wrong crosses , and that the true cross was not with this number at all .
Parsing [sent. 7307 len. 38]: However , as the woman seemed likely to die with the convulsions that were tearing her , they concluded that the third could do no more than put her out of her misery with a happy dispatch .
Parsing [sent. 7308 len. 11]: So they brought it , and behold , a miracle !
Parsing [sent. 7309 len. 17]: The woman sprang from her bed , smiling and joyful , and perfectly restored to health .
Parsing [sent. 7310 len. 14]: When we listen to evidence like this , we can not but believe .
Parsing [sent. 7311 len. 12]: We would be ashamed to doubt , and properly , too .
Parsing [sent. 7312 len. 14]: Even the very part of Jerusalem where this all occurred is there yet .
Parsing [sent. 7313 len. 9]: So there is really no room for doubt .
Parsing [sent. 7314 len. 31]: The priests tried to show us , through a small screen , a fragment of the genuine Pillar of Flagellation , to which Christ was bound when they scourged him .
Parsing [sent. 7315 len. 15]: But we could not see it , because it was dark inside the screen .
Parsing [sent. 7316 len. 35]: However , a baton is kept here , which the pilgrim thrusts through a hole in the screen , and then he no longer doubts that the true Pillar of Flagellation is in there .
Parsing [sent. 7317 len. 19]: He can not have any excuse to doubt it , for he can feel it with the stick .
Parsing [sent. 7318 len. 13]: He can feel it as distinctly as he could feel any thing .
Parsing [sent. 7319 len. 26]: Not far from here was a niche where they used to preserve a piece of the True Cross , but it is gone , now .
Parsing [sent. 7320 len. 12]: This piece of the cross was discovered in the sixteenth century .
Parsing [sent. 7321 len. 18]: The Latin priests say it was stolen away , long ago , by priests of another sect .
Parsing [sent. 7322 len. 35]: That seems like a hard statement to make , but we know very well that it was stolen , because we have seen it ourselves in several of the cathedrals of Italy and France .
Parsing [sent. 7323 len. 26]: But the relic that touched us most was the plain old sword of that stout Crusader , Godfrey of Bulloigne -- King Godfrey of Jerusalem .
Parsing [sent. 7324 len. 60]: No blade in Christendom wields such enchantment as this -- no blade of all that rust in the ancestral halls of Europe is able to invoke such visions of romance in the brain of him who looks upon it -- none that can prate of such chivalric deeds or tell such brave tales of the warrior days of old .
Parsing [sent. 7325 len. 39]: It stirs within a man every memory of the Holy Wars that has been sleeping in his brain for years , and peoples his thoughts with mail-clad images , with marching armies , with battles and with sieges .
Parsing [sent. 7326 len. 22]: It speaks to him of Baldwin , and Tancred , the princely Saladin , and great Richard of the Lion Heart .
Parsing [sent. 7327 len. 41]: It was with just such blades as these that these splendid heroes of romance used to segregate a man , so to speak , and leave the half of him to fall one way and the other half the other .
Parsing [sent. 7328 len. 22]: This very sword has cloven hundreds of Saracen Knights from crown to chin in those old times when Godfrey wielded it .
Parsing [sent. 7329 len. 18]: It was enchanted , then , by a genius that was under the command of King Solomon .
Parsing [sent. 7330 len. 25]: When danger approached its master 's tent it always struck the shield and clanged out a fierce alarm upon the startled ear of night .
Parsing [sent. 7331 len. 46]: In times of doubt , or in fog or darkness , if it were drawn from its sheath it would point instantly toward the foe , and thus reveal the way -- and it would also attempt to start after them of its own accord .
Parsing [sent. 7332 len. 37]: A Christian could not be so disguised that it would not know him and refuse to hurt him -- nor a Moslem so disguised that it would not leap from its scabbard and take his life .
Parsing [sent. 7333 len. 23]: These statements are all well authenticated in many legends that are among the most trustworthy legends the good old Catholic monks preserve .
Parsing [sent. 7334 len. 11]: I can never forget old Godfrey 's sword , now .
Parsing [sent. 7335 len. 16]: I tried it on a Moslem , and clove him in twain like a doughnut .
Parsing [sent. 7336 len. 25]: The spirit of Grimes was upon me , and if I had had a graveyard I would have destroyed all the infidels in Jerusalem .
Parsing [sent. 7337 len. 56]: I wiped the blood off the old sword and handed it back to the priest -- I did not want the fresh gore to obliterate those sacred spots that crimsoned its brightness one day six hundred years ago and thus gave Godfrey warning that before the sun went down his journey of life would end .
Parsing [sent. 7338 len. 43]: Still moving through the gloom of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre we came to a small chapel , hewn out of the rock -- a place which has been known as `` The Prison of Our Lord '' for many centuries .
Parsing [sent. 7339 len. 14]: Tradition says that here the Saviour was confined just previously to the crucifixion .
Parsing [sent. 7340 len. 16]: Under an altar by the door was a pair of stone stocks for human legs .
Parsing [sent. 7341 len. 28]: These things are called the `` Bonds of Christ , '' and the use they were once put to has given them the name they now bear .
Parsing [sent. 7342 len. 22]: The Greek Chapel is the most roomy , the richest and the showiest chapel in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre .
Parsing [sent. 7343 len. 30]: Its altar , like that of all the Greek churches , is a lofty screen that extends clear across the chapel , and is gorgeous with gilding and pictures .
Parsing [sent. 7344 len. 18]: The numerous lamps that hang before it are of gold and silver , and cost great sums .
Parsing [sent. 7345 len. 32]: But the feature of the place is a short column that rises from the middle of the marble pavement of the chapel , and marks the exact centre of the earth .
Parsing [sent. 7346 len. 50]: The most reliable traditions tell us that this was known to be the earth 's centre , ages ago , and that when Christ was upon earth he set all doubts upon the subject at rest forever , by stating with his own lips that the tradition was correct .
Parsing [sent. 7347 len. 16]: Remember , He said that that particular column stood upon the centre of the world .
Parsing [sent. 7348 len. 15]: If the centre of the world changes , the column changes its position accordingly .
Parsing [sent. 7349 len. 12]: This column has moved three different times of its own accord .
Parsing [sent. 7350 len. 55]: This is because , in great convulsions of nature , at three different times , masses of the earth -- whole ranges of mountains , probably -- have flown off into space , thus lessening the diameter of the earth , and changing the exact locality of its centre by a point or two .
Parsing [sent. 7351 len. 39]: This is a very curious and interesting circumstance , and is a withering rebuke to those philosophers who would make us believe that it is not possible for any portion of the earth to fly off into space .
Parsing [sent. 7352 len. 42]: To satisfy himself that this spot was really the centre of the earth , a sceptic once paid well for the privilege of ascending to the dome of the church to see if the sun gave him a shadow at noon .
Parsing [sent. 7353 len. 6]: He came down perfectly convinced .
Parsing [sent. 7354 len. 38]: The day was very cloudy and the sun threw no shadows at all ; but the man was satisfied that if the sun had come out and made shadows it could not have made any for him .
Parsing [sent. 7355 len. 16]: Proofs like these are not to be set aside by the idle tongues of cavilers .
Parsing [sent. 7356 len. 24]: To such as are not bigoted , and are willing to be convinced , they carry a conviction that nothing can ever shake .
Parsing [sent. 7357 len. 33]: If even greater proofs than those I have mentioned are wanted , to satisfy the headstrong and the foolish that this is the genuine centre of the earth , they are here .
Parsing [sent. 7358 len. 24]: The greatest of them lies in the fact that from under this very column was taken the dust from which Adam was made .
Parsing [sent. 7359 len. 12]: This can surely be regarded in the light of a settler .
Parsing [sent. 7360 len. 34]: It is not likely that the original first man would have been made from an inferior quality of earth when it was entirely convenient to get first quality from the world 's centre .
Parsing [sent. 7361 len. 8]: This will strike any reflecting mind forcibly .
Parsing [sent. 7362 len. 42]: That Adam was formed of dirt procured in this very spot is amply proven by the fact that in six thousand years no man has ever been able to prove that the dirt was not procured here whereof he was made .
Parsing [sent. 7363 len. 38]: It is a singular circumstance that right under the roof of this same great church , and not far away from that illustrious column , Adam himself , the father of the human race , lies buried .
Parsing [sent. 7364 len. 44]: There is no question that he is actually buried in the grave which is pointed out as his -- there can be none -- because it has never yet been proven that that grave is not the grave in which he is buried .
Parsing [sent. 7365 len. 5]: The tomb of Adam !
Parsing [sent. 7366 len. 37]: How touching it was , here in a land of strangers , far away from home , and friends , and all who cared for me , thus to discover the grave of a blood relation .
Parsing [sent. 7367 len. 11]: True , a distant one , but still a relation .

Parsing [sent. 7457 len. 43]: And so I close my chapter on the Church of the Holy Sepulchre -- the most sacred locality on earth to millions and millions of men , and women , and children , the noble and the humble , bond and free .
Parsing [sent. 7458 len. 22]: In its history from the first , and in its tremendous associations , it is the most illustrious edifice in Christendom .
Parsing [sent. 7459 len. 80]: With all its clap-trap side-shows and unseemly impostures of every kind , it is still grand , reverend , venerable -- for a god died there ; for fifteen hundred years its shrines have been wet with the tears of pilgrims from the earth 's remotest confines ; for more than two hundred , the most gallant knights that ever wielded sword wasted their lives away in a struggle to seize it and hold it sacred from infidel pollution .
Parsing [sent. 7460 len. 36]: Even in our own day a war , that cost millions of treasure and rivers of blood , was fought because two rival nations claimed the sole right to put a new dome upon it .
Parsing [sent. 7461 len. 47]: History is full of this old Church of the Holy Sepulchre -- full of blood that was shed because of the respect and the veneration in which men held the last resting-place of the meek and lowly , the mild and gentle , Prince of Peace !

Parsing [sent. 7485 len. 21]: The projections that answered for cheeks were worn smooth by the passionate kisses of generations of pilgrims from distant lands .

Parsing [sent. 7494 len. 55]: On the memorable day of the Crucifixion he stood in this old doorway with his arms akimbo , looking out upon the struggling mob that was approaching , and when the weary Saviour would have sat down and rested him a moment , pushed him rudely away and said , `` Move on ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7495 len. 26]: The Lord said , `` Move on , thou , likewise , '' and the command has never been revoked from that day to this .
Parsing [sent. 7496 len. 68]: All men know how that the miscreant upon whose head that just curse fell has roamed up and down the wide world , for ages and ages , seeking rest and never finding it -- courting death but always in vain -- longing to stop , in city , in wilderness , in desert solitudes , yet hearing always that relentless warning to march -- march on !
Parsing [sent. 7497 len. 94]: They say -- do these hoary traditions -- that when Titus sacked Jerusalem and slaughtered eleven hundred thousand Jews in her streets and by-ways , the Wandering Jew was seen always in the thickest of the fight , and that when battle-axes gleamed in the air , he bowed his head beneath them ; when swords flashed their deadly lightnings , he sprang in their way ; he bared his breast to whizzing javelins , to hissing arrows , to any and to every weapon that promised death and forgetfulness , and rest .
